quoteFirst: The bell is rung at half past two in the morning, and a man must be at his post by three. He gets half an hour each for breakfast and tea, and an hour for dinner; he works until
quoteLast: at night, and takes his supper when he gets through. If he is in debt to his employer, and the latter generally manages to have him so, he works every day—Sundays, Saints’ days, and all—through the season.
title: The Underground World: A mirror of life below the surface
author: Knox, Thomas Wallace, 1835-1896

quoteFirst: "I'll meet you at the hotel in Meander tomorrow morning
quoteLast: for a settlement, one way or the other."
title: Claim Number One
author: Ogden, George W. (George Washington), 1871-1966; St. John, J. Allen (James Allen), 1872-1957 [Illustrator]

quoteLast: until twelve, without one being sunk or so damaged as to lose speed. The enemy’s tactics included attacks by submarine and destroyer which had imposed the manœuvres as anticipated--and the best of gunnery had failed.
title: The British Navy in Battle
author: Pollen, Arthur Joseph Hungerford, 1866-1937

quoteLast: next morning Armstrong and Warrender rowed off in the dinghy; at a quarter to ten they entered the grounds of the Red House. The paths were weedy, the grass untrimmed, the flower-beds untidy.
title: No Man's Island
author: Strang, Herbert; Brock, C. E. (Charles Edmund), 1870-1938 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: They had nothing to look out for, however, on the out track except an accommodation that had started two hours previous. No. 999 had a light load, and she sped along without a jar. The wires took care of her. By
quoteLast: they were twenty miles "to the good" on regular schedule basis.
title: Ralph on the Overland Express; Or, The Trials and Triumphs of a Young Engineer
author: Chapman, Allen

quoteFirst: Josephine acquiesced with joy, and minutely followed the directions of Julia. All the young ladies went to bed
quoteLast: , but on this night it was long after ten before Josephine could compose herself to sleep. When every one in the house had gone to bed and all was quiet, Julia Dorival placed a taper in a small dark lantern, and proceeded with it to the passage into which Josephine's chamber opened.
title: The Hawthorne: A Christmas and New Years Present
author: Leslie, Eliza, 1787-1858 [Contributor]

quoteLast: his prison door was unlocked, and his Gaoler entering, commanded him to follow him. He obeyed with trembling.
title: The Monk: A Romance
author: Lewis, M. G. (Matthew Gregory), 1775-1818

quoteLast: that night I stood with Major Veasey outside our headquarters dug-out. A mizzling rain descended. Five substantial fires were burning beyond the heights where the Boche lay.
title: Pushed and the Return Push
author: Nichols, George Herbert Fosdike

quoteFirst: Drabdump closed the street door quietly, and pointed to the stairs, fear operating like a polite desire to give him precedence. Grodman ascended, amusement still glimmering in his eyes. Arrived on the landing he knocked peremptorily at the door, crying, "
quoteLast: , Mr. Constant; nine o'clock!" When he ceased there was no other sound or movement. His face grew more serious. He waited, then knocked, and cried louder. He turned the handle but the door was fast.
title: The Grey Wig: Stories and Novelettes
author: Zangwill, Israel, 1864-1926

quoteLast: , quite out of breath. He had just left a sitting of the Municipal Council which had been hastily summoned together. Choking with emotion, he announced that the mayor, Monsieur Garconnet, had declared, while making due reserves, that he was determined to preserve order by the most stringent measures.
title: The Fortune of the Rougons
author: Zola, Émile, 1840-1902; Vizetelly, Ernest Alfred, 1853-1922 [Editor]

quoteFirst: The Baroness Volterra drove to the Palazzo Conti in the heart of Rome at
quoteLast: , to be sure of finding Donna Clementina at home. She had tried twice to telephone, on the previous afternoon, but the central office had answered that "the communication was interrupted.
title: The Heart of Rome: A Tale of the "Lost Water"
author: Crawford, F. Marion (Francis Marion), 1854-1909

quoteFirst: They remained there till daylight, when one of the company knew that the place was "Cooper's Creek," a few miles above the "City of Brotherly Love." Immediately they made preparations to continue their journey, which had not been altogether unpleasant, and they were soon in full view of the city, where they arrived between eight and
quoteLast: on Sunday morning. They landed at Market Street Wharf. Taking out his money, which consisted of one unbroken dollar, and a shilling in copper coin, he offered the latter to the boatmen for his passage.
title:
The Printer Boy; Or, How Benjamin Franklin Made His Mark
An Example for Youth.
author: Thayer, William Makepeace, 1820-1898

quoteFirst: "This is evidently a lady's handkerchief, and is so important in the case, that I shall keep it until the trial is over. Bedney, come to my office by
quoteLast: to-morrow, as the Grand Jury may ask you some questions. Good bye, Dyce, shake hands; for I honor your loyalty to your poor young mistress, and her unfortunate child.
title: At the Mercy of Tiberius
author: Evans, Augusta J. (Augusta Jane), 1835-1909

quoteFirst: Until dark he plodded through the pages, then turned on the electric light.  Finding the book more difficult of comprehension than he had expected, he crouched over the volume, devoting his whole attention to the first few pages.
quoteLast: came and went.
title:
The Submarine Boys on Duty
Life on a Diving Torpedo Boat
author: Durham, Victor G.

quoteFirst: The last week in October we saw marvellous Northern Lights in Rome. The northern half of the heavens, about
quoteLast: in the evening, turned a flaming crimson, and white streaks traversed the red, against which the stars shone yellow, while every moment bluish flashes shot across the whole. When I discovered it I went up to the Reams' and fetched Vinnie down into the street to see it.
title: Recollections of My Childhood and Youth
author: Brandes, Georg, 1842-1927

quoteFirst: Major Worth was much affected by the loss of his dog, and did not join us at supper that night. We kept a nice fat quail for him, however, and at about
quoteLast: , when all was still and dark, Jack entered the Major's tent and said: "Come now, Major, my wife has sent you this nice quail; don't give up so about Pete, you know."
title: Vanished Arizona: Recollections of the Army Life by a New England Woman
author: Summerhayes, Martha, 1844-1926

title: The Mesmerist's Victim
author: Dumas, Alexandre, 1802-1870; Williams, Henry Llewellyn, 1842- [Translator]

quoteFirst: The first town I visited on this trip was Oconto, Wisconsin, which I reached the following morning; and before
quoteLast: I had made a cash sale of one hundred and fifty dollars, and went immediately to the express office and remitted it to the house. And as business was brisk I remitted from one to three hundred dollars per day to them.
title: Twenty Years of Hus'ling
author: Johnston, J. P. (James Perry), 1852-; Denslow, W. W. (William Wallace), 1856-1915 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: Moving cautiously during the day, in the advance, it halted for the night a short distance west of Ringgold, Georgia. At daybreak on the following morning we moved forward, and about
quoteLast: formed line of battle, remaining here during the day and subsequent night. The beat of the “long roll” on the following morning called us to arms, and we immediately advanced in line of battle.
title:
Journal History of the Twenty-Ninth Ohio Veteran Volunteers, 1861-1865

author: SeCheverell, J. Hamp (John Hamilton)

quoteFirst: And then there was the new foretopmast--promised
quoteLast: it was--not slung and stayed up until after ten. And then our second seine, which finally we had to leave for Wesley Marrs to take next morning. And there were the usual two or three men late.
title: The Seiners
author: Connolly, James B. (James Brendan), 1868-1957
